title: WHO's work towards vaccine equity continues in Africa and beyond
cleaned_text: Dr Matshidiso Moeti, Regional Director for Africa Region "Hundreds of WHO staff are on the ground, [ready to support countries to expand vaccination](/news/item/14-09-2021-leaders-make-urgent-call-to-accelerate-vaccination-globally-and-in-africa) sites and to manage the complexities of small deliveries of a variety of vaccines," WHO Regional Director for Africa Dr Matshidiso Moeti said. WHO continues its efforts to help roll out vaccines and fight COVID-19 on all fronts with the help of its donors and partners. Lesotho and Cameroon: Supporting communities with training, vaccination campaigns and fighting misinformation Published by WHO/AFRO on 17 September 2021 Myths and misinformation around COVID-19 vaccines are widespread in Lesotho. Over 85% of nearly 500 health workers surveyed recently reported widespread misconceptions. With support from WHO and the Christian Council of Lesotho, the [Ministry of Health is training religious leaders to spread life-saving facts on COVID-19](https://www.afro.who.int/news/raising-faith-covid-19-vaccines-lesotho) and COVID-19 vaccines. Six training sessions for 50 religious leaders have taken place in 5 of Lesotho's 10 districts so far, which have all been hit hard by COVID-19. Published by WHO/AFRO in September 2021 Local leaders supported by WHO - working with over 2,300 community mobilizers and 1,450 vaccination teams - carried out a [rapid COVID-19 vaccination drive of 52,000 people across Cameroon](https://www.afro.who.int/news/cameroons-community-leaders-drive-demand-covid-19-vaccines) in just 5 days. Among other activities, the drive included workshops on mobilizing communities and strengthening advocacy and access to resources for immunization campaigns. The sessions were run by the Ministry of Public Health with WHO, the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) and the German Agency for International Cooperation (GIZ). South Africa and the Americas: Building regional capacity to produce vaccines Published by WHO/AFRO in September 2021 WHO, a South African consortium and partners from COVAX are [working to set-up a technology transfer hub for mRNA vaccines in South Africa t](https://www.afro.who.int/news/towards-africas-first-mrna-vaccine-technology-transfer-hub)o help boost and scale up production in the African region. The hub will serve as a venue to teach African manufacturers to produce the vaccines locally, supporting the long-term plan of ensuring that Africa will be self-sufficient in making enough mRNA vaccines for its population. Currently, Africa imports around 90% of its vaccines. [The WHO Regional Office for the Americas (PAHO) has announced the selection of 2 centers](https://www.paho.org/en/news/21-9-2021-paho-selects-centers-argentina-brazil-develop-covid-19-mrna-vaccines) in Argentina and Brazil as regional hubs for the development and production of mRNA-based vaccines in Latin America in a bid to tackle COVID-19 and future infectious disease challenges. Afghanistan: WHO welcomes United Nations funding to fight COVID-19 and maintain health services WHO Director-General Dr Tedros (centre), WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, Dr Ahmed Al-Mandhari (centre left), and WHO Representative in Afghanistan Dr Luo Dapeng (centre right) stand together with nurses at the Wazir Mohammad Akbar Khan National Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, September 2021 The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) released US$45 million for the United Nations Central Emergency Response Fund to help keep Afghanistan's health facilities—including hospitals treating COVID-19 patients—operating until the end of the year. The funds will be used to support response efforts of WHO and UNICEF. Bolivia, Guatemala, Honduras, Rwanda and Sri Lanka: countries moving closer to vaccine equity Published by WHO/PAHO in September 2021 [Bolivia received 583,100 doses of COVID-19 vaccines donated by Spain and 97,800 donated by France](https://www.paho.org/es/noticias/20-9-2021-bolivia-recibe-vacunas-donadas-por-espana-francia-traves-covax) through the COVAX mechanism, co-led by WHO and partners. The recent shipment was the sixth the country has received so far from COVAX. [Guatemala received an additional 307,200 doses of COVID-19 vaccines](https://www.paho.org/es/noticias/17-9-2021-guatemala-recibe-307200-vacunas-donadas-por-gobierno-espana-traves-mecanismo) donated by Spain through COVAX. To date, Guatemala has received over 2.1 million doses through the mechanism. [Honduras received 180,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccines](https://www.paho.org/es/noticias/21-9-2021-honduras-recibe-180000-vacunas-donadas-por-espana-traves-covax) donated by Spain through COVAX. [Sri Lanka has reached the important milestone of having 50% of its population ](/srilanka/news/detail/18-09-2021-sri-lanka-vaccinates-50-per-cent-of-total-population)fully vaccinated with the support of WHO and COVAX. [Rwanda reached the target set by WHO of vaccinating 10% of its population](https://www.afro.who.int/news/rwanda-vaccinates-10-population-reaches-first-global-target) against COVID-19 by September 2021. WHO Director-General Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus acknowledged United States President Joe Biden for pledging to donate more vaccines to COVAX at the Global COVID-19 Summit at the United Nations General Assembly. ". . . [I thank him [ Joe Biden, President of the United States]](https://twitter.com/DrTedros/status/1440920267925114880) for his announcement to contribute another 500 million doses for vaccine equity," Dr Tedros said. Published by the WHO Viet Nam Country Office in September 2021 [Viet Nam received a delivery of 852,480 COVID-19 vaccine doses](/vietnam/news/detail/16-09-2021-joining-hands-to-fight-the-pandemic-germany-supports-viet-nam-with-852.480-vaccine-doses-via-covax) donated by Germany. Viet Nam has so far received approximately 12.5 million doses of COVID-19 vaccines via COVAX. South Sudan: Strengthening health facilities at points of entry Dr Fabian Ndenzako, the WHO Representative a.i. for South Sudan during the handover ceremony at Juba International Airport. Published by WHO/AFRO in September [WHO, with support from the Government of Japan, has established and handed over a port health facility](https://www.afro.who.int/news/who-and-government-japan-establish-port-health-facility-juba-international-airport-enhance) at the Juba International Airport to the Ministry of Health in South Sudan. The facility will improve the country's coordination and communication capacity to mitigate the risk of cross-border spread of disease such as COVID-19 as well as other public health threats. **** [Learn how WHO supports countries around the world in strengthening their health systems to deliver health for all through a primary health care approach.](https://www.uhcpartnership.net/covid-19-stories-from-the-field/) Partners and donors recognized in this feature are the governments of Germany, Japan, Spain as well as COVAX and UNICEF.
